Graphical abstract Methane dehydroaromatization is studied using different loadings (0.2 wt%, 0.6 and 1 wt%) of Co and Ni additives on a 6 wt% Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst to evaluate the promoting effect of Ni and Co on reactivity and stability of the catalysts. A synergy between Mo and the additives is observed when combining a reduction/carburization pretreatment with an optimum additive loading: benzene yield and catalytic stability are both improved. The fresh and spent samples were characterized by X-Ray Diffraction, 27Al Magic-Angle Spinning Solid State Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy, Temperature-Programmed Reduction and Thermogravimetric Analysis. The results suggest that catalytic enhancement in precarburized Mo-Co and Mo-Ni samples is due to a combination of effects: extraction of Al from the ZSM-5 framework to form inactive Al2(MoO4)3 is reduced, interaction of Mo with the additives enhances the retention of Mo species within the zeolite channels, prevents Mo aggregation in reaction and modifies the reducibility of the Mo sites. Keywords Methane dehydroaromatization Benzene 6 wt% Mo/HZSM-5 Co-modified Mo catalysts Regeneration 1 Introduction Natural gas is an abundant fossil fuel, mainly composed of methane, which is used as feedstock in the chemicals manufacturing industry. The high transportation costs of a gas however, are causing much of the newly discovered natural gas to be flared, resulting in the underutilization of an otherwise valuable resource, as well as emission of CO2 into the atmosphere. It is therefore desirable to develop processes to upgrade natural gas to added-value products in one step. The routes for upgrading methane can be classified in two major groups: (i) indirect conversion processes and (ii) direct conversion processes. Indirect conversion involves two steps, where methane is first converted to syngas by partial oxidation or by reforming and in the second step, syngas is converted to other valuable products such as alkenes, paraffins, higher alcohols, methanol, dimethyl ether, by Fischer-Tropsch process or by methanol to hydrocarbon catalysis [1]. In the direct conversion routes, the intermediate syngas step is skipped, and methane is directly converted to added-value products in a single step, thus reducing processing costs. Examples of direct conversion include oxidative coupling of methane (OCM), direct conversion to oxygenates, for example methanol [2,3] and dehydroaromatization reaction to aromatics [4]. Since Wang et al. [5] reported the first active catalyst in 1993 for non-oxidative methane dehydroaromatization (MDA), which converts methane to aromatic compounds and hydrogen, using MoOx supported on ZSM-5, extensive investigation has been carried out on zeolite-supported molybdenum oxide catalysts [6–23]. However, detrimental coke formation which causes relatively fast deactivation of the catalysts is a major hindrance towards commercialization of the MDA process. The commonly accepted reaction pathway indicates that during the reaction induction period, the supported Mo oxide species are carburized by methane to Mo oxycarbide and then carbide species which are then responsible of activating the C–H bond of methane, which in turn leads to the formation of ethylene that undergoes oligomerization on the zeolite Brønsted acid sites, eventually forming aromatics [24–26]. Recently it was demonstrated that benzene is only formed when the Mo oxycarbide species are fully carburized to form unanchored Mo carbide clusters within the channels [27]. Over time, the larger aromatic molecules that cannot leave the zeolite channels form carbon deposits which, along with those formed due to methane cracking on the external surface sites, deactivate the catalyst. In an attempt to improve the catalytic performance, multiple studies have been performed by adding other metal promoters to the Mo catalysts, with additives such as Cu [28,29], Cr [30], Zn [31,32], P [33], Ga [34,35] and Ag [31,36]. Although results are not conclusive and the enhancement is short-lived, specifically Fe [37], Co [38–41] and Ni [42] are promising additives in Mo-based catalysts employed in MDA. Aboul-Gheit et al. [37] tested 6Mo/ZSM-5, 3Mo-3Fe/ZSM-5, 3Mo-3Co/ZSM-5, and 3Mo-3Ni/ZSM-5 (numbers indicate wt %) with N2 pretreatment for MDA and observed that adding Fe, Co, and Ni decreased the benzene yield compared to the unmodified 6Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst. The decrease was in the order Fe > Co > Ni and they explained it based on the deficiency in electrons in these elements, which causes them to form a strong interaction with the H+ sites of the zeolite. In other words, strong metal-support interactions cause the Brønsted acid sites, responsible for aromatization of the C2 species, to be occupied and thus selectivity to benzene is inhibited. Thus, the results in this work suggest that relatively high additive loadings do not have a promoting effect on the Mo catalysts since they deplete the catalyst of the acid sites. Other groups found that presence of optimum additive loadings, restricted to very low weight percent can be beneficial to the reaction. Vosmerikov et al. [42] tested catalysts consisting of 4 wt% Mo supported on HZSM-5, modified with 0.1–2 wt% Ni and found that indeed the catalyst with lower amount of Ni additive (0.1 wt%) exhibited the best catalytic properties, while higher amounts of Ni resulted in fast catalytic deactivation caused by a higher rate of formation of filamentous carbon deposits. The enhancing effect of Ni was explained due to its higher hydrogenation character. Burns et al. [38] tested Co-modified catalysts containing 3 wt% Mo on HZSM-5 modified with Co using a Co/Mo molar ratio of 0.25. They observed an initial boost in catalytic activity with Co however the effect was transitory. In separate papers, Liu et al. [39] and Tang et al. [40] modified a 3 wt% Mo catalyst with 1 wt% Co and reported an increase in benzene yield from 3.2%–4.7 % and 3.8%–7.6% respectively, however no stability data was reported. More recently, Fila et al. [41] tested Co-Mo/ZSM5 catalysts in MDA at high pressures with Co loadings ranging from 0.4 to 1.6 wt% and found that the optimum loading of Co for a 4 wt% Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst was 0.8 wt%, rendering the highest and most stable total benzene production. While all these studies show enhancement of catalytic benzene yield with addition of specific amounts of additives, the improvements are temporary, and the catalysts still deactivate after relatively short periods of reaction time. Recently, our group discovered that HZSM-5 supported Mo carbides synthesized ex situ exhibit better catalytic properties in MDA compared to supported Mo oxides, where the active carbide species are formed in situ during the reaction induction period [43,44]. When Mo carbides are formed in situ, they are formed by preheating the Mo oxide species in He up to reaction temperature and then exposing them to CH4 reactant, which acts as carburizing agent. During the heating stage in He and in the reaction induction period, the Mo oxide species, which are volatile, have the chance to migrate and block the zeolite pores, before converting to non-volatile reduced Mo species, thus causing faster catalyst deactivation than in carbides formed ex situ, where the Mo carbide species formed under reduction at lower temperatures [43,44] are incapable of migrating within the zeolite channels to the same degree as Mo oxides. Some groups have found that an additional contributing factor to catalyst deactivation at high Mo loadings is the formation of Al2(MoO4)3 species due to extraction of Al from the ZSM-5 framework when Mo loadings are high, exceeding 6 wt % [45–47]. When studying the effect of adding Fe to a ZSM-5 supported Mo oxide catalyst [48] we found that adding 0.2 wt% of Fe to the precarburized catalysts further enhanced the benzene yield and catalyst stability. While no mixed Mo-Fe phases were detected, it is possible that the ability of Fe to form carbidic phases makes it an effective additive for Mo-based catalysts employed in MDA. Based on this assumption, Co and Ni, which are elements within the iron group (first row in Group VIII) in the periodic table, could also interact with Mo carbide in a similar way, and potentially serve as promoters in Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts. As a natural extension of our previous work, here our aim is to investigate the effect of adding specific amounts of Co and Ni in ZSM-5 supported Mo catalysts employing both He pretreatment and precarburization. To remain consistent with our past work [48], we have prepared catalysts using the same Mo loading, 6 wt% Mo, and low additive loadings, specifically, 0.2, 0.6 and 1 wt% of Co and Ni. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Commercial ZSM-5 (Si/Al = 15, Zeolyst International) was used as the support for the catalysts. The commercial ZSM-5 was first calcined at 500 °C with ramp rate of 2 °C/min for 6 h to convert the zeolite powder from its ammonium form to its protonated form. Molybdenum oxide was supported on the zeolite using the conventional incipient wetness impregnation method. Ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate (Sigma Aldrich), ferric nitrate nonahydrate (Sigma Aldrich), cobalt nitrate (Sigma Aldrich) and nickel nitrate (Sigma Aldrich) were used as the metal precursors for Mo, Fe, Co, and Ni respectively. Sequential impregnation method was employed to prepare the ZSM-5 supported mixed Mo-X (X = Fe, Ni, Co) catalysts using the above-mentioned precursors. The resulting samples were then dried overnight and calcined in the furnace at 110 °C with a ramp rate of 1 °C/min and held at this temperature for 2 h, followed by calcination at 500 °C at 1 °C/min for 5 h. The catalysts that were prepared contained 6 wt% Mo and different amounts of metal additive (0, 0.2, 0.6, and 1 wt%) and are respectively designated as 6Mo, 6Mo-0.2X, and 6Mo-1X (X = Co or Ni). 2.2 Catalyst reactivity The catalysts were tested in a fixed-bed tubular quartz reactor with 8 mm inner diameter and a length of 300 mm. The catalyst bed consisted of 300 mg of sample with particle size within the range of 125–250 microns, held in place between two quartz wool plugs. The samples were heated to 700 °C with a 5 or 10 °C/min temperature ramp, under specific gas flow rates which varied based on the pretreatment condition employed (described in the following paragraph); after temperature equilibration at 700 °C was achieved, reaction conditions were applied by flowing 91 % CH4/N2 into the reactor at atmospheric pressure and at a space velocity of 1500 ml/g⋅h. With nitrogen as an internal standard, the products leaving the reactor were analyzed using an online gas chromatograph equipped with flame ionization detector and thermal conductivity detector (Shimadzu). Two pretreatment methods were tested: (a) heating the catalyst to 700 °C under He flow at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min (b) reducing the catalyst with a CH4/H2 (1:9, v/v) mixture to 700 °C at a ramp rate of 5 °C/min, and then carburizing for 10 min. under pure CH4 at 700 °C. We will refer to this second pretreatment method as “precarburization”. The samples that were pretreated in He have been denoted as “sample name – He”. 2.3 Catalyst regeneration For the regeneration study, the catalysts were exposed to reaction conditions for 10 h and then the gas flow was switched to 95 ml/min of H2 flow for 1 h at atmospheric pressure. The catalysts were exposed to reaction conditions for 430 min after the first regeneration. 2.4 Catalyst characterization Both fresh and spent catalysts were characterized by the following characterization methods. 2.4.1 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms Textural characteristics of the samples was determined by adsorption of nitrogen at −196 °C using Quantachrome Autosorb IQ. The sample was outgassed at 350 °C for a minimum of 2 h and then cooled to −196 °C. Adsorption isotherms were then recorded as a function of relative pressure and specific volume of nitrogen adsorbed at Standard Temperature and Pressure (STP). The surface area of the samples was determined using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. 2.4.2 X-ray diffraction of the catalysts (XRD) X-Ray diffraction patterns of the catalyst were obtained using Rigaku Ultima III PXRD with CuK α radiation at 40 kV and 20 mA. The data was recorded at 2θ between 5° to 60° at a scan speed of 0.25°/min. 2.4.3 Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) TPR was carried out on fresh catalysts before pretreatment using Quantachrome-Autosorb IQ. In order to maintain consistency, 0.0700 g of the sample was heated to 500 °C at 20 °C /min under He flow, and held for 30 min., after which the sample was brought back to room temperature. The gas was switched from He to 5 % H2/He, and the sample was heated to 1000 °C at 10 °C /min. The data was recorded using an in-built TCD. 2.4.4 Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) TGA was performed on the spent catalysts using METTLER TGA/SDTA851e. 0.015 g of sample was heated to 1000 °C at 10 °C /min under airflow of 50 ml/min. The amount of coke in the spent catalyst was calculated as follows [49]: C o k e a m o u n t ( m g / g . c a t ) = M 1 - M 2 M 2 × 1000 Where M1 denotes the weight percent of the coked catalyst before coke burn-off, and M2 denotes the weight percent of the coked catalyst after coke burn-off. 2.4.5 27Al magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (27Al MAS-NMR) All samples were packed into standard wall 3.2 mm pencil rotors (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA and Loveland, CO) to a standard volume of 22 μL. All 27Al spectra were recorded on an Agilent DD2 600 MHz (14.1 T) spectrometer (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA and Loveland, CO) equipped with a BALUN 3.2 mm probe. At this field strength the 27Al resonance frequency is 156.4 MHz and the 27Al signal of an aqueous 1 M Al(NO3)3 solution was used as a universal chemical shift reference. The magic-angle spinning (MAS) rate was maintained at 15,000 ± 3 kHz. The sample temperature setpoint was 10 °C, corresponding to a sample temperature of 16 ± 2 °C. All 27Al spectra were acquired with a π/12 excitation pulse (1.2 μs). Spectra were acquired without high powered decoupling on 1H after it was confirmed 1H decoupling minimally impacted the observed spectra. All spectra were processed using NMRPipe by Fourier transformation after apodization with a sinebell window function. All peaks were selected and integrated using nonlinear line shape fitting functionality within NMRPipe. Because each rotor contained slightly different total moles 27Al, each with different relative coordination environment populations, all spectra were normalized using the sum of all peak integrated intensities. 1H spectra were also acquired to confirm all samples were hydrated after exposure to high temperatures (data not shown). 2.4.6 Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) The surface morphology of the samples was assessed using Hitachi-H-800 scanning electron microscope. Fresh catalyst samples were analyzed at 8–10 kV, while the spent samples were analyzed at 8 kV. 2.4.7 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) X-Ray Photoelectron spectra (XPS) were collected using a Physical Electronics PHI 5700 spectrometer with non-monochromatic Mg Kα radiation (300 W, 15 kV, 1253.6 eV) for the analysis of the core level signals of C 1s, O 1s, Ti 2p and Au 4f and with a multi-channel detector. Binding energy (BE) values were referenced to the C 1s peak (284.8 eV) from the adventitious contamination layer. The spectrometer energy scale was calibrated using Cu 2p 3/2, Ag 3d 5/2, and Au 4f 7/2 photoelectron lines at 932.7, 368.3, and 84.0 eV, respectively. The PHI ACCESS ESCA-V6.0 F software package and Multipak v8.2b were used for acquisition and data analysis, respectively. A Shirley-type background was subtracted from the signals. Recorded spectra were always fitted using Gauss-Lorentz curves, in order to determine the binding energy of the different element core levels more accurately. The error in BE was estimated to be ca. 0.1 eV. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic results Fig. 1 (a) and (b) represent the benzene yield obtained over time on stream (TOS) for all the precarburized Mo-based catalysts (red symbols) with 6 wt% Mo and different amounts of a second metal additive, X (X = Co or Ni). To serve as reference, the data points corresponding to He pretreated catalysts have also been included (blue symbols). Based on our past studies monitoring evolution of Mo species from oxides to carbides, the induction period of Mo catalysts occurs within the first 40 min of reaction [43–48]. Similarly, the data points represented in Fig. 1 after 40 min correspond to the catalytic activity after the induction period. It is clear that the reduction/carburization pretreatment enhances the benzene yield obtained with each catalyst, with respect to its He-pretreated counterpart, regardless of the nature and amount of the additive metal loading, in line with what was observed when using Fe as additive [48]. As we have demonstrated in our past work, this enhancement is due to a higher dispersion of the Mo species when the catalysts are precarburized [43,44]. The effect of the additive type and loading on benzene yield varies depending on the type of pretreatment received. For the He-pretreated catalysts (Fig. 1, blue symbols), adding 0.2. 0.6 and 1 wt% Co reduces the benzene yield; adding 0.6 and 1 % Ni reduces it, and 0.2 wt% Ni hardly affects the yield. In other words, no overall catalytic enhancement is observed by addition of Co or Ni when the catalysts are pretreated in He. The behavior of the precarburized catalysts follows a different trend: precarburization of 6Mo increases the benzene yield and its stability over time compared to its He pretreated version. Adding Co or Ni enhances the benzene yield even further, but the effect depends on the loading employed for each additive. In the case of Co, adding 0.2 wt% Co (6Mo-0.2Co catalyst) hardly changes the activity compared to 6Mo, however when its loading is increased to 0.6 wt%, Co enhances benzene yield over the entire reaction period time. Upon increasing Co loading to 1 wt% the overall enhancement is not significant compared to 6Mo-0.6Co; initially, and up to 150 min. into reaction, no enhancement in benzene yield is observed compared to 6Mo, and after that time, the benzene yield remains stable while that of 6Mo drops slightly, increasing the difference in benzene yield between the two catalysts over time. When Ni is used as additive, 0.2 and 0.6 wt% Ni loading result in very similar overall benzene yield enhancement. When Ni loading is increased to 1 wt%, the effect is similar to the case of 1 wt% Co: no yield enhancement is observed during the first minutes of reaction after the induction period, however over longer reaction times, the difference between 6Mo and 6Mo-1Co becomes larger due to the higher stability of the latter. These results indicate that, as in the case of Fe [48], there are optimum Co and Ni loadings that provide higher and more stable benzene yields, and this amount varies depending on the nature of the additive. In the case of Ni, a loading as small as 0.2 wt% benefits the Mo catalyst, whereas for Co, a slightly higher amount, 0.6 wt% is required to optimize benzene yield. These numbers are similar to the ones reported in the literature; Fila et al. [41] point to 0.8 wt% of Co as optimum additive loading for a 4 wt% Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst, and Vosmerikov et al. [42] found that a lower loading of Ni additive (0.1 % in 4 wt% Mo catalyst) had a higher enhancing effect compared to higher Ni loadings. These works however did not involve precarburization of the catalysts, thus the enhancement observed was temporary and the catalyst deactivation problem was not overcome, with benzene yields eventually decreasing after several hours. Clearly catalyst stability is an important feature of the modified precarburized catalysts. To analyze the deactivation rates, the first order deactivation constants, kD , for all the catalysts were calculated from the slopes of the semilogarithmic plot of the rate of formation of benzene as a function of TOS (shown in Fig. S1 in the Supplementary information section) from the moment that the rate of formation of benzene begins to drop. The kD values for the precarburized catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . (The semilogarithmic plots and kD values obtained for selected He-pretreated catalysts are shown in Fig. S2 and Table S1 respectively.) As would be expected, the kD values are higher in the case of the less stable, He-pretreated catalysts. As for the precarburized catalysts, the effect of the addition of both Co and Ni is evident on the kD values, which become smaller when the additives are present. Moreover, higher loadings of each additive promote the catalytic stability to a larger extent as is evidenced by the smaller kD values obtained for 6Mo-0.6Co, 6Mo-1Co, 6Mo-0.6Ni and 6Mo-1Ni. This phenomenon could be explained by secondary methane cracking reactions caused by the additives, Co and Ni, where H2 is formed and is capable of gasifying part of the carbon deposited in reaction in situ, thus increasing catalyst stability. The evolution of CH4 conversion and the selectivity to different products (other than benzene) with TOS for the precarburized and He-pretreated catalysts are represented respectively in Figs. S3 and S4. Apart from benzene, formation of ethylene, toluene and naphthalene are also observed, although the selectivities to these products are low compared to benzene. It is worth noting that the catalysts presenting lower selectivity to aromatics show higher ethylene selectivity, indicating that although they present a lower overall selectivity to aromatics, they still possess active Mo-C sites capable of activating CH4 and leading to CC coupling. Analyzing the activity of the single-metal additive catalysts, Co/ZSM-5 and Ni/ZSM-5 (Tables S2 and S3 respectively), can help to understand how the additives contribute to the overall catalytic activity of the Mo-Co and Mo-Ni catalysts. It is observed that all the single metal Co catalysts, 0.2Co, 0.6Co and 1Co are capable of activating CH4 since CH4 conversion values > 0 % are measured (∼2 % CH4 conversion); a study of the yield to other products however shows absence of products formed from CC coupling: ethylene or aromatics, therefore Co is only capable of cracking CH4 to H2 and coke in the absence of Mo. This phenomenon can explain why the CH4 conversion values obtained after the induction period for the Mo-Co catalysts, within the range of 12–16%, are higher than thermodynamic equilibrium conversion (12 %) calculated theoretically for conversion of methane to benzene [50]. Despite the incapability of the Co species to produce benzene in the single-metal Co/ZSM-5 catalysts, when they are added to 6Mo in the Mo-Co catalysts (red symbols in Fig. 1(a)), their presence results in an enhancement in benzene yield, therefore, the combination of Co with Mo has a synergistic effect on the production of benzene and other aromatics at 0.2 and 0.6 wt% of Co. At 1 wt% loading the enhancement is simply due to the higher stability conferred to the catalyst and is mostly evident after four hours of reaction. A similar analysis can be performed with the Ni catalysts. For the single metal Ni catalysts, 0.2Ni does not produce any ethylene or aromatics (Table S3), yet the addition of 0.2 wt% of Ni to 6Mo (6Mo-0.2Ni) produces an enhancement in benzene yield. For the 0.6Ni catalyst benzene and some naphthalene begin to form after around 470 min of time on stream, yet the benzene yield obtained with the 6Mo-0.6Ni catalyst is higher than that of 6Mo from the early stages of reaction after the induction period, and gradually the difference in benzene yield increases, partly due to an additive contribution of benzene formed by Ni species. The fact that the benzene yield in the Mo modified catalysts, 6Mo-0.2Ni and 6Mo-0.6Ni, is higher than the sum of the benzene yields obtained separately with 6Mo and 0.2Ni and 0.6Ni respectively during the first minutes of reaction after the induction period, is indicative that here also, a synergy exists between Mo and Ni in the Mo-Ni catalysts, that results in an enhancement in the benzene yield. 3.2 Structural characterization of the as-synthesized, pretreated and spent catalysts 3.2.1 X-ray diffraction (XRD) To identify the structure of the crystalline phases in the catalysts, XRD patterns of the as-prepared, pretreated and spent catalysts were acquired and are presented in Fig. 2 (a)–(e). (The XRD patterns within the range 2θ = 5-50° are represented in Fig. S5.). Two important aspects can be highlighted generally: (1) ZSM-5 diffraction peaks appear in all the XRD patterns of the fresh and spent catalysts, however, in all the cases, the intensity of the ZSM-5 peaks within the 2θ = 5-10° range is slightly weaker compared to the pure ZSM-5 reference due to incorporation of the metal species in the micropore channel structure of the zeolite [51]; (2) all figures show that the addition of a second metal does not result in the detection of any new mixed Mo-Co or Mo-Ni crystalline phases regardless of the type of pretreatment employed. The absence of peaks corresponding to mixed Mo-Co and Mo-Ni phases does not prove their non-existence, however, if they are present, they are probably in the form of small clusters that are not detectable by XRD. It is important to note that since Mo species inside the zeolite channels are too small to be detected by XRD, it is reasonable to assume that any Mo phases detected here reside on the external surface of the zeolite. The XRD patterns of the fresh as-synthesized catalysts are shown in Fig. 2(a). The peak at 2θ = 27.3° corresponds to crystalline MoO3 (JCPDS File No. 05-05058). This peak partially overlaps with the weak ZSM-5 peak at 27.5°, however its relative high intensity with respect to the ZSM-5 peak appearing at 26.9° indicates the additive effect of the ZSM-5 peak with that of MoO3 crystals when both phases coexist. The intensity of the MoO3 peak decreases generally with the addition of a second metal (Co or Ni), and the effect is bigger as the loadings of the additives become larger. This phenomenon probably occurs due to an interaction of the second metal with the Mo oxide, although it is not possible to distinguish whether the effect is caused by a decrease in the crystallinity of the Mo oxide by distortion caused by interaction of the additive with the MoO3, or a reduction of the quantity of Mo oxide species residing on the external surface of the zeolite, or both TPR measurements of the as-synthesized catalysts before pretreatment (discussed in Section 3.2.2 . Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) below) provide more structural information that can further explain these patterns. The XRD patterns of the pretreated catalysts are represented in Fig. 2(b) and (c). The patterns of the He-pretreated catalysts are similar to those of the as-synthesized catalysts although the intensity of the peak corresponding to MoO3 decreases relative to the ZSM-5 peak, pointing to a higher dispersion of the Mo species in the 6Mo catalyst. No peaks corresponding to extraframework Al2(MoO4)3 species are observed in the XRD patterns [47], indicating that if zeolite dealumination has occurred, it has not happened to a great extent. Notwithstanding, we have performed 27Al-MAS-ss NMR measurements to detect formation of extraframework Al species (see Section 3.2.3 . 27Al-MAS-NMR). Most of the precarburized catalysts exhibit a broad peak around 2θ = 39.5°, attributed to Mo2C (JCPDS File No. 35-0787), while the MoO3 peak is absent in all of them, indicating that during precarburization, the crystalline Mo oxide phases present on the external surface of the catalyst are reduced and carburized. The absence of Mo2C peaks in 6Mo-0.6Co and 6Mo-0.6Ni is probably due to better dispersion of the carburized Mo species in these samples. No other mixed Mo-Co or Mo-Ni phases are detected. Comparing the XRD patterns of the spent He pretreated and precarburized catalysts, in Fig. 2(d) and (e), it is observed that for the spent He pretreated catalysts the MoO3 peak completely disappears and instead a broad Mo2C peak appears. This is expected since it has long been agreed among researchers that during the induction period of the reaction the Mo oxide species convert to Mo carbide species that are responsible for aromatization to occur [13,24–26]. In the case of the precarburized catalysts, Mo2C peak was already present in the fresh catalysts, and after reaction, the Mo2C peaks become more intense when the additive is at its highest loading, i.e. 1 wt%, indicating sintering of the Mo2C phases located on the external surface of the zeolite. 3.2.2 Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) TPR was performed on the fresh as-synthesized oxide catalysts to verify the effect of the presence of a second metal, Co or Ni, on the reduction profile of the catalysts before receiving any type of pretreatment. The profiles present different reduction features in the 300–900 °C range depending on both additive type and loading (Fig. 3 ). All the catalysts exhibit three distinct peaks in the range of 400 °C–810 °C (Fig. 3(a) and (b)). Moreover, the weak reduction feature between 300–400 °C is related to the partial reduction of amorphous polymeric molybdate species [52]. This contribution is similar for all samples. Previous research has shown that bulk MoO3 reduction happens in a two-step process where MoO3 gets reduced to MoO2 (Mo6+→Mo4+) and MoO2 is further reduced to Mo (Mo4+ →Mo0) [53]. When Mo oxides are supported on SiO2 or Al2O3 the TPR profiles change however [54,55], due to the interactions of the Mo oxide species with the support. Based on previous TPR studies of supported Mo oxides [54–59], for the catalysts employed in the current work, the TPR peak appearing at a lower temperature (510 °C) can be assigned to the complete reduction of amorphous, poly-molybdate species that are non-uniformly distributed on the external surface of the zeolite (Mo6+→Mo0), whereas the peak at 580 °C can be assigned to the partial reduction of Mo6+ oxide species associated to Brønsted acid sites, located inside the zeolite channels, to Mo4+ oxide species (Mo6+→Mo4+) [59]. The peak at 710 °C is attributed to the reduction of Mo4+ →Mo0. The fact that the area underneath the 710 °C peak is not double that of the area under the lower temperature peaks indicates that not all the species are fully reduced by the end of the TPR experiment and that a sequential reduction process is not occurring. Addition of promoters to 6Mo/HZSM-5 changes the position of the reduction peaks of the catalysts, as observed in Fig. 3. To analyze the effect of the additives on Mo, the TPR profiles of monometallic Co and Ni samples were also measured. The Co catalysts did not consume hydrogen (profiles not shown), which could be ascribed to highly dispersed Co particles of small size as observed for other metals [60]. On the other hand, Ni samples show a broad reduction profile with a maximum centered at 410–420 °C, which is associated to reduction of unbounded NiO [61] (profile shown in Fig. S6). In the case of Co-modified Mo catalyst (Fig. 3(a)), the low and high temperature peaks shift slightly to higher temperatures upon adding Co (from 510 °C to 535 °C; and from 710 °C to around 810 °C, respectively), however the position of the peak at 580 °C hardly changes, although its intensity does increase. Based on the TPR peak assignment of Hongmei et al. [59], the results presented here suggest that the presence of Co affects the reducibility of the Mo oxide species on the external surface of the zeolite, while promoting the retention of Mo oxide species inside the zeolite channels. Since the latter are inside a confined space, with channels of ZSM-5 being 5 Å in diameter, they are not detectable by XRD, explaining thus the lower intensity of the MoO3 peak observed in the XRD patterns of the Co-modified catalysts. In the case of Ni-modified Mo catalysts (Fig. 3(b)), at increasing Ni loadings the reduction peaks at 510 and 580 °C shift to lower temperature, thus the presence of Ni promotes the reducibility of MoO3 species. It is the peak at 710 °C that remains unaltered. 6Mo-0.2Ni sample presents an important increase in the intensity of the band at 580 °C, that now presents a shoulder at ca. 535 °C. Therefore, a greater proportion of MoO3 species inside the ZSM-5 channels seem to be present in this catalyst. Further Ni addition shifts MoO3 reduction bands to lower temperatures that overlap with that of NiO reduction (see Fig. S6), indicating that MoO3 reduction is improved under Ni presence. Moreover, the contribution due to MoO3 inside zeolite channels shows a higher peak intensity and therefore, as in the case of Co, indicates that Ni additive is capable of improving Mo dispersion. These data are in accordance with those obtained from XRD of the as-synthesized catalysts (Fig. 2(a)). The TPR profiles therefore corroborate the fact that the Mo oxide species are electronically modified by the presence of Co and Ni. While Co addition seems to improve MoO3 dispersion inside the zeolite channels, Ni presence improves MoO3 dispersion and affects its reducibility. 3.2.3 N2 adsorption isotherms and BET surface area The N2 adsorption isotherms of the fresh and spent catalysts are represented in Figs. S7 and S8. All the catalysts exhibit Type IV isotherms, indicating presence of micropores with some mesopores. Table 2 summarizes the BET surface area of the as-synthesized, pretreated and spent catalysts. Although the pretreated catalysts do show slightly lower surface areas compared to their as-synthesized counterparts, these differences fall within the error range of the instrument, discarding any specific trend. Moreover, the type of pretreatment received for each catalyst loading does not modify the surface area significantly. The addition of any amount of Ni and Co leaves the surface area of the as-synthesized catalysts insignificantly changed. A clear trend however is observed when comparing the % drop in surface area from pretreated to spent catalysts: the drop is generally higher for the He-pretreated catalysts compared to the precarburized ones, for example, 6Mo-0.2Co shows a drop in surface area of 36 % when it is He-pretreated, versus 9 % when it is precarburized. The trends in the % drop in surface areas from pretreated to spent catalysts correlate with the difference in catalytic stability of the two groups of catalysts, where precarburized catalysts are more stable (as observed earlier when comparing the kD values in Tables 1 and S1). It is noteworthy that for the He-pretreated samples, the addition of Co and Ni result in a higher surface area of the spent catalysts compared to the unmodified 6Mo catalyst: the latter undergoes a 61 % reduction in surface area, versus 41 % when 0.2 wt% Co is added (6Mo-0.2Co) or 26 % when 0.2 wt% Ni is added (6Mo-0.2Ni). The observed differences in the % drop in surface area are in line with the stability trends observed in the activity data for these catalysts. When 1 wt % of additive is present, in 6Mo-1Co and 6Mo-1Ni, the fall in surface area from fresh to spent sample is almost the same for both kinds of pretreatment. There are various possible scenarios that could explain the differences in drop in surface area and catalyst deactivation for the two groups of catalysts: (1) the Mo could extract Al from the zeolite framework to form Al2(MoO4)3 with a consequent collapse of the zeolite structure. The following sections address these possibilities; (2) the zeolite pores could be blocked by formation of carbon deposits. The following sections will address these two hypotheses by measuring the coordination of Al species formed after pretreatment (by 27Al MAS-ssNMR in Section 3.2.4.) and by quantifying the coke formed in reaction (by TGA in Section 3.2.5.) respectively. 3.2.4 Magic-angle spinning solid-state NMR (27Al MAS-ssNMR) When extraframework Al2(MoO4)3 species that are inactive in MDA are formed on Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts, the process is accompanied by a collapse of the ZSM-5 zeolite structure, evidenced by a drop in the BET surface area, a decrease in the intensity of the XRD ZSM-5 peaks, and fast catalyst deactivation. Our BET data (Table 2) do not show a difference in the surface area of the catalysts undergoing the different types of pretreatment and furthermore, the intensity of the ZSM-5 peaks do not decrease significantly upon pretreatment, discarding the possibility of a collapse of the ZSM-5 framework in our deactivated catalysts. Yet, it is important to determine if Al2(MoO4)3 species are formed, even if the quantities are low, since they can still contribute to catalyst deactivation by forming at the expense of the MDA-active Mo species that were originally anchored to the ZSM-5 framework. 27Al MAS-ssNMR was conducted to investigate the changes in coordination of the Al species present in the 6Mo catalyst upon calcination, He pretreatment and precarburization and the spectra presented in Fig. 4 show that the type of pretreatment strongly modifies the MAS-NMR spectrum. Table 3 presents the chemical shift and the relative population based upon integrated intensity (volume) of each peak. All the samples present peaks near 0, 14 and 54 ppm. We attribute these peaks to octahedrally coordinated extraframework aluminum, hydrated Al2(MoO4)3 and tetrahedrally coordinated framework aluminum respectively [45–47,62]. A weak peak at 32 ppm also appears in all samples, showing its highest intensity in the He-pretreated sample. This peak has been assigned to penta-coordinated or highly distorted tetrahedrally coordinated extraframework aluminum [63,64]. This same sample also presents an additional peak at -14 ppm, which has also been assigned to Al2(MoO4)3 [47]. The relative populations of extraframework 27Al increase in both pretreated catalysts relative to the aluminum population still observed within the zeolite framework. In the case of the precarburized 6Mo catalyst, the relative population of Al2(MoO4)3 increases from ∼12 % to ∼15 %. A greater diversity of extraframework 27Al is observed in the He-pretreated catalyst, including a unique strongly upfield shifted population of octahedrally coordinated 27Al at -14 ppm, with the population of Al2(MoO4)3 increasing up to ∼24 %. Thus the data suggest that with He-pretreatment more Al sites are extracted from the zeolite framework and while the BET and XRD results suggest that this extraction does not happen to a significant extent, the NMR spectra indicate a clear difference in the degree of extraction for the different pretreatment conditions, which can explain the differences observed in the catalytic stability. Since the drop in surface area in the deactivated catalysts is not explained by the dealumination, it is necessary to test the second hypothesis, that pore blocking is caused by formation of coke. The latter is analyzed by thermogravimetric analysis. 3.2.5 Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) To analyze the amount of carbon deposits present in the spent catalysts, TGA measurements were performed; the TGA profiles are shown in Figs. S9–S11. All the profiles exhibit an initial weight loss below 250 °C attributed to the loss of absorbed ambient humidity [65]. At temperatures above 370 °C, the profiles present a slight weight gain attributed to the oxidation of the Mo carbide species in air to MoO3, which has a higher molecular weight compared to Mo2C [66]. In the samples studied here, other metals (Co or Ni) coexist with Mo and it is likely that they are either reduced or forming a mixed phase with the Mo carbide species, therefore the weight gain cannot be attributed only to formation of MoO3. Weight loss observed between 480 °C and 680 °C corresponds to the burn-off of coke that has deposited during reaction [67]. The latter was quantified according to reference [49] in the Experimental section and values are shown in Table 4a . When comparing catalysts with the same type of additive, the general trend observed is that, both in He-pretreated and precarburized samples the amount of deposited carbon increases with additive loading, i.e. from 0.2 wt% to 1 wt%, which further corroborates that the additives probably contribute to reaction by cracking of CH4 to form coke. Comparing the amount of carbon deposited during reaction in the precarburized catalysts versus the He-pretreated ones, it is evident that there is always more coke formation in the former ones, which are interestingly the more stable catalysts. In other words, the quantity of carbonaceous deposits formed in reaction does not correlate with the decrease in surface area of the spent catalysts, refuting the hypothesis that pore blocking and consequent deactivation are caused only by formation of carbon deposits. It is possible that the changes in surface area after reaction are due to a phenomenon that is unrelated to carbon. Our previous work comparing Mo carbide species formed ex situ (precarburized samples) versus those formed in situ (He-pretreated samples) points to more Mo aggregation in He-pretreated catalysts [43,44], however this work was carried out using extremely high Mo loading (10 wt%). Here, the Mo loading is almost half, 6 wt%, and we do not observe a significant change in the BET surface area after pretreatment. In fact the surface area does not change much between treatment in He or in CH4. But Mo aggregation during reaction cannot be discarded, since in the He-pretreated catalyst the mobile Mo oxide species are present at the beginning of reaction when the temperature is high (700 °C), while the precarburized catalysts only present less mobile Mo carbide species when exposed to pure methane. Furthermore, this argument can be extended to the precarburized additive-modified catalysts in this work, by speculating that the presence of Co and Ni additives can further reduce the mobility of the Mo species while they are being precarburized. In order to test this hypothesis, TGA of the fresh as-synthesized Mo-Co and Mo-Ni catalysts was performed to evaluate whether the presence of the additives was impacting the volatility and mobility of the species at high temperatures. The TGA profiles of the in Fig. 5 show a drop in weight at temperatures above 700 °C, corresponding to volatilization of the metal species. The temperature at which this happens, shown in Table 4b , varies depending on the amount of additives employed. Clearly a trend is observed: the presence of both additives increases the temperature, which becomes higher as additive loading increases, suggesting that both Co and Ni interact with the Mo species, decreasing their mobility and volatility, and that this interaction is stronger as additive loading increases. The effect is more marked with Ni additive versus Co. This finding suggests that by adding Co and Ni, these species are capable of retaining the Mo species at higher temperatures, thus reducing possible sintering within the channels and their consequent blocking, contributing to a higher stability in the formation of benzene over reaction time. This also explains why no big drop in surface area is observed for the He-pretreated 6Mo-1Co and 6Mo-1Ni catalysts since the presence of larger amounts of the additives are capable of reducing the mobility of the Mo oxide species even under high temperatures, thus preventing their aggregation. Furthermore, this hypothesis is aligned with the tendencies observed by the XRD patterns of the as-synthesized catalysts (i.e. before pretreatment) (Fig. 2(a)) where presence of the additives results in a drop in the intensity of the most intense peak corresponding to MoO3 crystals, indicating that the additive interacts with Mo on the external surface, reducing its crystallinity and distorting it. XPS spectra of the precarburized catalysts were also measured before and after reaction and are presented in Fig. S12 in the SI section. The Mo/(Si + Al) atomic ratios measured by XPS are representative mostly of the external surface of the zeolite and provide an idea of the degree of exposure of Mo on the surface. The data indicate that upon adding both the Co and Ni additive, the Mo exposure reaches a maximum value with 0.6 wt% loading but then decreases when increased to 1 % both in the fresh and spent samples, once again in line with the activity data of the precarburized catalysts where the highest stability is obtained with the catalysts containing 0.6 wt% of the additives TGA measurements were also performed on the spent precarburized single-metal additive catalysts, Co/ZSM-5 and Ni/ZSM-5. The amount of carbon deposited in reaction calculated from the TGA profiles (Fig. S11) is shown in Table 5 . The sum of the amount of carbon deposits formed with 6Mo and each of the Co and Ni catalysts is higher than the amount of carbon deposits formed in the Mo-Co and Mo-Ni catalysts (with the exception of 1 Co), showing that in the presence of Mo, the cracking capacity of the additive metals, Co and Ni, is reduced, further suggesting that a Mo-Co and Mo-Ni interaction affects the activity of both the Mo and the additive species when they coexist on ZSM-5. Testing the blank ZSM-5 in reaction produces a small amount of carbon deposits (first row in Table 5), discarding a significant contribution of the zeolite support to the formation of carbon deposits in the single-metal additive samples. 3.2.6 Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) Figs. S13 and S14 represent the SEM images of the spent He-pretreated catalysts and spent precarburized catalysts respectively: (a) 6Mo-0.2Co (b) 6Mo-0.6Co (c) 6Mo-1Co (d) 6Mo-0.2Ni (e) 6Mo-0.6Ni (f) 6Mo-1Ni. No major morphological change was observed between the two types of pretreated catalysts, but extensive carbon nanotube formations were observed in both spent precarburized and He-pretreated catalysts with the higher, 1 wt% loading of additive, 6Mo-1Co/ZSM-5 and 6Mo-1Ni/ZSM-5. This is in agreement with reports that Co and Ni are responsible for the catalytic thermal decomposition of CH4 to nanostructured carbon materials [68–70]. However, in the case of the precarburized catalysts, the amount of carbon nanotubes formed in reaction is clearly lower at lower additive loadings, therefore it can be claimed that for all three additives, when their loadings are low, precarburization inhibits the formation of carbon nanotubes. Small amount of carbon nanotubes was observed in spent oxide catalysts, 6Mo-0.2Co/ZSM-5 and 6Mo-0.2Ni/ZSM-5. On the other hand, in the spent precarburized catalysts, carbon nanotubes were observed only in 6Mo-0.2Ni/ZSM-5, but not in 6Mo-0.2Co/ZSM-5 catalysts. 3.3 Regeneration cycles on spent catalysts The interaction between Mo and the additives, Co or Ni, in the precarburized catalysts can have an additional practical benefit over time: it can facilitate the regeneration of the catalysts without affecting their stability over several regeneration cycles. To test this, two regeneration cycles under hydrogen flow were applied after being exposed to 10 h of reaction and the evolution of the benzene yield over TOS over the cycles is illustrated in Fig. 6 . The catalysts picked for this study were the Co- and Ni-modified catalysts with optimum additive loadings, 6Mo-0.6Co and 6Mo-0.2Ni, and each were compared to the unmodified 6Mo catalyst. We observe that both the precarburized 6Mo-0.6Co/ZSM-5 and 6Mo-0.2Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts not only present a higher benzene yield compared to unmodified 6Mo, but also higher stability over each regeneration cycle: the 6Mo catalyst recovers part of the benzene yield after each regeneration, however over TOS, its yield slightly drops; but in the case of both of the modified catalysts, 6Mo-0.6Co and 6Mo-0.2Ni, not only is the benezene yield obtained after the regeneration slightly higher, but also remains stable and even increases slightly over time. While not in the scope of the work presented here, further structural characterization before and after each cycle would be necessary to further relate the differences in behavior of these catalysts with the regeneration cycles. 4 Conclusions The effect of adding Co and Ni to Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts varies depending on the type of pretreatment received. When Mo carbides are formed in situ, during the reaction induction period (after He pretreatment) the presence of additives is detrimental to their catalytic activity and benzene yield. However, when the catalysts are precarburized, a synergy is established in the presence of an optimum loading of both Co and Ni rendering catalysts that produce higher and more stable benzene yields. This behavior is due to the combination of various effects: (1) precarburization diminishes formation of inactive Al2(MoO4)3 species as well as preventing aggregation of Mo species during the reaction induction period; (2) the presence of additives further decreases the volatility and mobility of the Mo species, possibly enhancing the retention of the Mo species inside the zeolite channels during reaction and reducing catalyst deactivation; (3) when Mo and the additive species coexist, no crystalline mixed phases are observed, however their interaction modifies the activity of the individual metals, benefitting the selectivity towards benzene. Both Co- and Ni-modified catalysts present higher catalytic stability after several regeneration cycles compared to the unmodified Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Methane dehydroaromatization is studied using different loadings (0.2 wt%, 0.6 and 1 wt%) of Co and Ni additives on a 6 wt% Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst to evaluate the promoting effect of Ni and Co on reactivity and stability of the catalysts. A synergy between Mo and the additives is observed when combining a reduction/carburization pretreatment with an optimum additive loading: benzene yield and catalytic stability are both improved. The fresh and spent samples were characterized by X-Ray Diffraction, 27Al Magic-Angle Spinning Solid State Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy, Temperature-Programmed Reduction and Thermogravimetric Analysis. The results suggest that catalytic enhancement in precarburized Mo-Co and Mo-Ni samples is due to a combination of effects: extraction of Al from the ZSM-5 framework to form inactive Al2(MoO4)3 is reduced, interaction of Mo with the additives enhances the retention of Mo species within the zeolite channels, prevents Mo aggregation in reaction and modifies the reducibility of the Mo sites.
coredata.dc:title: Bimetallic Mo-Co/ZSM-5 and Mo-Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts for methane dehydroaromatization: A study of the effect of pretreatment and metal loadings on the catalytic behavior
